text: (light contemporary music)

- For me, it's always
been about the patients.

I grew up on three continents
by the time I was 18,
and I've seen the impact on human health
from the most developed country
to the most developing country.
And I think there's a lot we can do
to level the playing field,

in terms of healthcare and
the impact for patients.

The combination of data
science and science

is really advancing
how we can help humans.
In order to develop a medicine,
it takes us years.
(droplet splashes)
But I think there's so much opportunity
using data science, AI, machine learning,

to not just shave the
time, that's one aspect.
But I think the more important aspect
is insight that lets you know early on
that something's not gonna be toxic,

that something is gonna have
a better safety profile,

that something truly
can be transformational.
And this led us

to the Amazon Machine
Learning Solutions Lab.

Using some of the differentiated
capabilities AWS has,
from a data integration perspective,
and then coupling that with our know-how
on chemistry data, on biological data,
adding a powerful search engine,
and then applying AI machine learning

to be able to predict
which of these molecules

would have the best chance
of being a medicine.
With the open-mindedness and creativeness
of using data science,
we're in the best position,
and the central point, to help patients.

That's what gets me
outta bed every morning.
(light contemporary music fades)
